column1: Aortic angiography is a procedure that uses a special dye and x-rays to see how blood flows through the aorta.
Arteries are blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart.
This test is done at a hospital.
The doctor can see live images of the aorta on a TV-like monitor, and x-rays are used to guide the catheter to the correct position.

Tell your health care provider: - If you are pregnant - If you have ever had any allergic reactions to x-ray contrast material or iodine substances - If you are allergic to any medicines - Which medicines you are taking (including any herbal preparations) - If you have ever had any bleeding problems

Risks of aortic angiography include: - Allergic reaction to the contrast dye - Blockage of the artery - Blood clot that travels to the lungs - Bruising at the site of catheter insertion - Damage to the blood vessel where the needle and catheter are inserted - Excessive bleeding or a blood clot where the catheter is inserted, which can reduce blood flow to the leg - Heart attack or stroke - Hematoma, a collection of blood at the site of the needle puncture - Infection - Injury to the nerves at the needle puncture site - Kidney damage from the dye
This procedure may be combined with left heart catheterization to look for coronary artery disease.
